newsitem.title: CHINA: China approves two Huaneng power projects.
newsitem.headline: China approves two Huaneng power projects.

text.p: Chinese authorities have approved the construction of two power projects in eastern China by China's Huaneng International Power Co and two foreign consortiums, company officials said on Thursday.

China's State Council, or cabinet, on Wednesday approved the two projects to expand power generation facilities in Fuzhou in eastern Fujian province and in Nantong in eastern Jiangsu province, a Huaneng official said by telephone.
Although contracts for the projects had been signed in June, central government approval was necessary because of the large amount of investment involved, the official said.

The Nantong project involved investment of $273.6 million, with U.S. firms General Electric Co, Babcock and Wilcox, and Black and Veatch to supply two 350 megawatt coal-fired generators and related equipment, he said.
Export credits from the United States accounted for 85 percent of project financing, with the remaining 15 percent coming from commercial loans, he said.
Germany's Siemens and Japan's Mitsui Babcock Energy would supply two 350 megawatt generators for the Fuzhou expansion, with investment totalling $271 million, he said.
Germany, the United Kingdom and the United States had granted export credits totalling 85 percent of investment while commercial loans made up the other 15 percent, he said.
The expansions would double current generating capacity at the plants, both of which have twin 350-megawatt generators, he said.
The first generating units for both projects were expected to be installed in 1998 and the second units in 1999, he added.
